title: Effort to Stem Deaths Among Children Falls Short of Goals, Report Says
text:
Husaina Saidu, left, and her child, who survived an attack in northwest Nigeria, went to a hospital in Kaduna in February.

Nearly two-thirds of children in developing countries live in villages, cities or regions where deaths under 5 years of age aren’t declining rapidly enough to meet United Nations goals, according to a new report released Tuesday. .

The findings come from “Goalkeepers,” an annual report card published by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation on the progress countries are making to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals—targets for 2030 agreed on by U.N. member countries.

The SDG targets include reducing deaths of children under 5 years old to 25 or fewer for every 1,000 live births by 2030. Globally, under-5 deaths were 39 per 1,000 live births in 2017, according to the U.N.

The targets also include ensuring that all children receive a quality primary and secondary education.

One-third of children live in places that won’t meet that goal by 2050, according to the Goalkeepers report.

“We’re not really converging the way that you would expect,” said Bill Gates, the billionaire philanthropist who co-chairs the foundation with his wife, Melinda Gates, in an interview. At the current rate of improvement in child mortality rates, as well as educational attainment, at the end of the century there “will still be a dramatic level of inequality, super dramatic,” he said.

The shift is particularly alarming because population growth is higher in parts of the world that lag the most behind, Mr. Gates said.

Health and education are key measures of human capital—the best way for a country to unlock innovation and generate prosperity, the Gates Foundation says. The Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, which it funds, analyzed both by geographical location to pinpoint where the divide is occurring. It examined progress in 17,144 “districts” or counties in 97 low- and middle-income countries.

People in the vast majority of the developing world are healthier and better educated today than they were at the beginning of this century, the analysis found. In 2000, 59 countries had rates of under-5 mortality of 69 per 1,000 live births, the average at that time, according to the IHME analysis. Millions of young children were dying of pneumonia, measles and diarrheal diseases. Another 51 countries had an under-5 mortality rate of more than 25, the current SDG target for 2030.

By 2017, only 20 countries had a rate above 70, the result of new efforts to vaccinate children against preventable diseases, and more effective prevention of illnesses such as malaria. The remaining countries were concentrated almost entirely in the Sahel region of Africa, a band that stretches across Africa below the Sahara Desert.

But compared with the rest of the world, these countries are far behind. Literacy rates are low in the Sahel, and under-5 mortality is higher than anywhere else in the world. Yet its population is skyrocketing,

There are stark disparities within countries of the Sahel, the IHME district-level analysis shows. Mali and Nigeria are prime examples. Southeastern Mali is plagued with drought and desertification—a slow expansion of the desert onto fertile lands. Northern Nigeria has been impoverished historically compared with the rest of the country, and attacks from Boko Haram, the group that aims to create an Islamic State in Nigeria, have created further instability.

Improvements in health and education since 2000 also differ by district. Garki, a city in northern Nigeria, had one of the highest rates of under-5 mortality and lowest rates of educational attainment in 2000. It has improved, but that has only brought it up to the bottom of today’s rankings. Oredo-Edo, a district in the south of the country, by contrast, has improved at a slower rate but is still at the top. Even today, disparities across Nigeria remain great.
